What are some possible warnings you might encounter when installing Verus software, and how do VerusIDs work?

When installing Verus software, you might encounter warnings from certain antivirus programs, such as Avast and Kaspersky, flagging the software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP" (Potentially Unwanted Program). These warnings are simply alerts that you are installing mining software, which could potentially be used by a third party to exploit your computer. However, these warnings are false positives, and you can find more information about them from resources such as Malwarebytes and Kaspersky.

Now, about VerusIDs: VerusIDs are a fully functional blockchain protocol, not just an ID system. Unlike many other blockchain ID implementations, there is no corporation involved in the protocol. VerusIDs provide a wide range of opportunities for identity applications. Specifically, VerusID provides various features, including quantum-ready friendly crypto-addresses on the worldwide Verus network, full decentralization, revocability, recoverability, privacy, and power. These features make VerusIDs a robust and secure way to manage identities on the blockchain.

Avast and Kaspersky may flag the software as "not-a-virus" or "PUP". These are warnings that you are installing mining software, which may be installed by a third party to exploit your PC.
To find out more about the false positives, review the following resources:
https://blog.malwarebytes.com/detections/pup-optional-bitcoinminer/
